courses.course_name: Critical Reading and Response to Literature
courses.description:
LITC-GE 2005 Critical Reading and Response to Literature 
Development of processes and skills for teaching critical evaluation of fiction and nonfiction to elementary school children.  Ways to stimulate and evaluate response to literature are examined as means of developing appreciation of quality in literature and lifetime habit of reading.

LITC-GE 2006 Literature for Younger Children 
Consideration of literature and literacy materials especially suitable for children in nursery school, kindergarten, and grades one, two, and three.  Special attention is given to the storytelling arts and to the use of literature in the classroom.

LITC-GE 2007 Literature for Older Children 
Consideration of literature and literacy materials especially suitable for children and youths in the upper elementary school years and junior high school.  Special attention is given to the storytelling arts and to the use of literature in the classroom.

courses.course_name: Language as a Basis for Teaching Read & Writing
courses.description:
LITC-GE 2008 Language as a Basis for Teaching Read & Writing 
Consideration of literature and literacy materials especially suitable for children in nursery school, kindergarten, and grades one, two, and three.  Special attention is given to the storytelling arts and to the use of literature in the classroom.

LITC-GE 2010 First & Second Language Development 
Survey of theories of oral language acquisition and development in first and second languages and the role of language as a foundation for classroom discourse and early literacy. Attention to the role of talk across the curriculum and a survey of principles, observation, and instructional practices for supporting a language and literacy rich curriculum. Study of linguistic diversity including English as a second language, varieties of English, and language delay and difference, as it impacts school-based language and literacy learning and academic achievement will be explored.

LITC-GE 2011 Literacy Assessment 
Survey of principles and practices of formal and informal literacy assessment. Critical examination of test types, methods of test construction and interpretation, and large-scale literacy evaluation. Review of measurement concepts and psychometric principles. Use of dynamic assessment to inform the design, monitoring, and evaluation of literacy instruction. The social implications of testing are explored with a focus on the politics of testing and the relationship between testing practices, learner diversity, and system decision making.

LITC-GE 2012 Reading Theory/Practice in Early Childhood/Childhood 
Survey of reading process theory and related reading assessment and instruction practices. Study of reading development in early childhood and childhood.  Focus on teaching comprehension, study skills, word identification, vocabulary development, phonemic awareness, and phonics skills. Special emphasis on individual differences and potential difficulties in reading development and methods for planning reading instruction for struggling or reluctant readers.

courses.course_name: Literacy Ed Early Chldhd Chldhd II
courses.description:
LITC-GE 2013 Literacy Ed Early Chldhd Chldhd II 
Survey of writing process theory and related assessment and instruction practices with a focus on standards-base curriculum planning. Students plan and take part in writing activities in order to acquire pedagogical knowledge in writing. Special emphasis on writing development through early childhood and childhood. Exploration of the relationship between reading, writing, and literacy development.

LITC-GE 2014 Reading Theory/Practice in Middle Childhood/Adolescence 
Survey of reading process theory and related reading assessment and instruction practices. Study of reading development in middle childhood and adolescence. Focus on teaching comprehension, study skills, word identification, vocabulary development, phonemic awareness, &, when necessary, phonemic awareness and phonics skills. Special emphasis on individual differences and potential difficulties in reading development and methods for planning reading instruction for struggling or reluctant readers.

LITC-GE 2015 Literacy Ed Mc/Adol II 
Survey of writing process theory and related assessment and instruction practices with a focus on standards-based curriculum planning. Students focus on and take part in writing activities in order to acquire pedagogical knowledge in writing. Special emphasis on writing development through middle childhood and adolescence. Exploration of the relationship between reading, writing, and literacy development.

LITC-GE 2016 Politics and Policies of Literacy 
An examination and critical evaluation of the theories of the reading and writing process as well as related methods of assessment and instruction. Theoretical frameworks are used to identify and respond to individual differences and potential difficulties in developing reading and writing skills and strategies in diverse student populations in the areas of phonemic awareness, phonics, spelling, fluency, vocabulary development, comprehension, study skills, and composing.

LITC-GE 2017 Text, Tools and Culture 
Children's and adolescent literature as primary tools in the teaching of reaching comprehension from a critical perspective. Strategies for locating, selecting, and evaluating resources and materials for use in classroom literacy programs, and selecting  texts that appeal to reluctant readers and students with special needs. Emphasis is placed on teaching children's literature multiculturally.

courses.description:
LITC-GE 2040 Wilson Intro to Multisensory Structured Language Instruction 
This course provides an introduction to multisensory structured language instruction with the Wilson Reading System ® (WRS). There are eight sessions in this course examining reading research & the five areas of reading in relation to students beyond grade two with persistent phonological coding deficits. This course addresses WRS, including student identification & placement, WRS program implementation, WRS lesson planning, progress monitoring scheduling, creating a successful classroom environment, principles of language structure, & how to teach language with direct, multisensory methods.

LITC-GE 2041

Presents the details of multisensory structured language instruction required for teaching students beyond grade two with word-level deficits who haven’t responded to previous phonics instruction. This on-line course provides practical application of reading research, with particular emphasis on phonological awareness, phonics & spelling at beginning levels.  Provides specific procedures to teach concepts presented in Wilson Reading System (WRS) Steps 1-3. LITC-GE 2048 Psych Found Literacy 
Development of an understanding of the reading process in a psychological framework.  Provides a survey of the theories underlying the assessment of reading disabilities and related learning areas.  Emphasizes the importance of understanding diagnostic data for effective intervention.

LITC-GE 2050 Found Literacy Instruct Exceptional Children 
Focuses on the theoretical aspects of language and reading.  Emphasizes the teaching of reading comprehension in relation to special education populations.  Current reading materials are analyzed from a psycho-linguistic perspective.

courses.course_name: Pract Assessmnat Oral and Written Lang
courses.description:
LITC-GE 2051 Pract Assessmnat Oral and Written Lang 
Diagnosis of reading disability cases of children under supervision: interview procedures, individual informal assessment techniques, interpretation of data, recommendations for intervention both in school and at home.  Practicum work is supplemented by demonstrations, observations, lectures, and discussions of the diagnosis of reading problems affecting children.  Students reflect on their use of diagnostic techniques by viewing videos made during their interaction with their children.

LITC-GE 2052 Pract Literacy Intervent Strategies 
Intervention with individual reading disability cases of children under supervision, including teaching strategies, lesson planning, instructional materials, and recommendations for follow-up work.  Practicum experience is supplemented by observations, lectures, and demonstrations of techniques for use with children with reading disabilities.  Students reflect on their use of intervention strategies by viewing videos made during their interaction with their children.

LITC-GE 2054 Cli Fldwk Pract Literacy 
Observation and participation in reading clinics, schools, and public and voluntary agencies serving children and young adults with reading and learning problems.  Students are supervised by licensed reading specialists.

LITC-GE 2056 Prep-Eval Rdng Material 
Selecting and critiquing specific reading and writing materials for individual children and groups.  Materials may be used in conjunction with E63.2052.  Class discussion, individual and small group work, including conferences for evaluation of narrative and expository texts as well as computer software.

LITC-GE 2057 Content Area Rdng Wrtng 
Focuses on reading theories as they relate to methods and materials used with students in elementary and secondary schools and colleges.  Reading strategies needed for effective comprehension and study are stressed across the curriculum.

LITC-GE 2060 Literacy Assessmnt/Intrv Strat Exceptional Child 
Diagnosis and intervention of reading disability cases of exceptional children under supervision; interview procedures, individual informal assessment techniques, interpretation of data, lesson planning, and recommendations for intervention.  Practicum work is supplemented by demonstrations and viewing videos made during students' interactions with their children.

LITC-GE 2065 Admin/Supv Literacy Prog 
Exploration of the role of the literacy specialist within the school community with special attention to professional development, literacy program implementation and supervision, and student assessment responsibilities. The range of functions of the literacy specialist will be considered in light of how these are impacted by the changing needs of the school community and political exigencies. Field participation is required.

LITC-GE 2300 Independent Study 
It should be noted that independent study requires a minimum of 45 hours of work per point. Independent study cannot be applied to the established professional education sequence in teaching curricula. Each departmental program has established its own maximum credit allowance for independent study. This information may be obtained from a student?s department. Prior to registering for independent study, each student should obtain an Independent Study Approval Form from the adviser.

LITC-GE 2991 Clinical Literacy Practicm-Early Childhood/Childhood 
One semester supervised practicum in early childhood and childhood classroom. Practicum experiences will be used to support theoretical and practical applications of the planning and implementation of the curriculum.

LITC-GE 2992 Clinical Literacy Practicum Middle Childhood/Adolescene 
One semester supervised practicum in middle childhood/adolescent classroom. Practicum experiences will be used to support theoretical and practical applications of the planning and implementation of the curriculum.
